{"abstract": "My dog is always ready to move on and look for something new. I can relate.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/01/16/what-i-miss-when-im-in-china-and-arizona/", "snippet": "My dog is always ready to move on and look for something new. I can relate.", "lead_paragraph": "My husband and I have a German shepherd mix named Raz that we rescued when he was a 9-month-old puppy. Today, Raz is always thrilled to go anywhere, whether it\u2019s to the park or to visit the vet. I joke with my managers that I wish our employees jumped up and down and yodeled with joy upon arriving at our company\u2019s office the way Raz does.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "What I Miss When I\u2019m in China (and Arizona)", "kicker": "You're the Boss", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Americans Abroad", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Small Business", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Weidenhamer, Deb", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "ARIZONA", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2014-01-16T20:00:14+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Entrepreneurship", "byline": {"original": "By Deb Weidenhamer", "person": [{"firstname": "Deb", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Weidenhamer", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/fc610012-110a-559d-89f2-a42d0f24f1b4", "word_count": 716, "uri": "nyt://article/fc610012-110a-559d-89f2-a42d0f24f1b4"}

{"abstract": "In China, customer service is handled quite differently. {"abstract": "Investors may be betting that Alibaba will move into digital entertainment, but they are too easily excited, contends Robyn Mak of Reuters Breakingviews.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/03/13/star-struck-by-alibaba-movie-company-deal/", "snippet": "Investors may be betting that Alibaba will move into digital entertainment, but they are too easily excited, contends Robyn Mak of Reuters Breakingviews.", "lead_paragraph": "The e-commerce giant Alibaba\u2019s latest deal shows the extent of investor frenzy for China\u2019s Internet. The company announced on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy 60 percent of the ChinaVision Media Group, which is listed in Hong Kong, for $804 million. The film company\u2019s market value promptly soared to almost $5 billion. Star-struck investors are too easily excited.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Star-Struck by Alibaba\u2019s Movie Company Deal", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Ma, Jack", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "ALIBABA.COM", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2014-03-13T16:09:10+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Robyn Mak", "person": [{"firstname": "Robyn", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Mak", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/e5b401cf-c6da-50a4-bd49-dca3c64b2922", "word_count": 392, "uri": "nyt://article/e5b401cf-c6da-50a4-bd49-dca3c64b2922"}

{"abstract": "The growth of the Twitter-like Chinese microblog Weibo comes with some hairy regulatory risks, John Foley of Reuters Breakingviews writes.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/03/17/weibo-i-p-o-sets-a-low-bar-for-alibaba/", "snippet": "The growth of the Twitter-like Chinese microblog Weibo comes with some hairy regulatory risks, John Foley of Reuters Breakingviews writes.", "lead_paragraph": "Imagine the riskiest possible share offering. It would be a new, unprofitable company with rapid and uncertain growth in an emerging market. One whose customers are fickle, which lives under the constant threat of being snuffed out by regulators, and where external shareholders are dominated by insiders. The listing of Sina Weibo fits the bill. The Twitter-like microblog has also set a low bar for the upcoming market debut of the e-commerce giant Alibaba.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "xlarge", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2014/03/17/business/dbpix-weibo/dbpix-weibo-articleLarge.jpg", "height": 400, "width": 600, "subType": "xlarge", "crop_name": "articleLarge", "legacy": {"xlarge": "images/2014/03/17/business/dbpix-weibo/dbpix-weibo-articleLarge.jpg", "xlargewidth": 600, "xlargeheight": 400}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "jumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2014/03/17/business/dbpix-weibo/dbpix-weibo-jumbo.jpg", "height": 683, "width": 1024, "subType": "jumbo", "crop_name": "jumbo", "legacy": {}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "superJumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2014/03/17/business/dbpix-weibo/dbpix-weibo-superJumbo.jpg", "height": 1366, "width": 2048, "subType": "superJumbo", "crop_name": "superJumbo", "legacy": {}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "thumbnail", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2014/03/17/business/dbpix-weibo/dbpix-weibo-thumbStandard.jpg", "height": 75, "width": 75, "subType": "thumbnail", "crop_name": "thumbStandard", "legacy": {"thumbnail": "images/2014/03/17/business/dbpix-weibo/dbpix-weibo-thumbStandard.jpg", "thumbnailwidth": 75, "thumbnailheight": 75}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "thumbLarge", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2014/03/17/business/dbpix-weibo/dbpix-weibo-thumbLarge.jpg", "height": 150, "width": 150, "subType": "thumbLarge", "crop_name": "thumbLarge", "legacy": {}}], "headline": {"main": "Weibo I.P.O. {"abstract": "Han Sanping is stepping down as chairman of the China Film Group, a government-sponsored company that supervises film imports to China.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/19/business/media/confirmation-of-shake-up-in-chinas-film-industry.html", "snippet": "Han Sanping is stepping down as chairman of the China Film Group, a government-sponsored company that supervises film imports to China.", "lead_paragraph": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 Even more mysterious than the subterranean power struggles in Hollywood are the hidden currents in China\u2019s growing film business. {"abstract": "A severe slowdown in China\u2019s economy would have a modest ripple effect, particularly on global commodity prices, but would not provoke a global crisis, two economists write.", "web_url": "https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/03/27/chinas-shadow-banking-malaise/", "snippet": "A severe slowdown in China\u2019s economy would have a modest ripple effect, particularly on global commodity prices, but would not provoke a global crisis, two economists write.", "lead_paragraph": "Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention and a research associate at the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. {"abstract": "Expanding into China can be daunting, but without a sales strategy that includes Asia, companies risk missing many opportunities.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/05/05/helping-small-companies-go-big-in-china/", "snippet": "Expanding into China can be daunting, but without a sales strategy that includes Asia, companies risk missing many opportunities.", "lead_paragraph": "When I encounter other American companies that do business in China, I am often surprised by the relatively small size of their operations in the United States. {"abstract": "Software, sensors and data make it possible to monitor and measure work as never before. {"abstract": "There are three major differences between the way e-commerce works in the United States and in China.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/07/07/learning-the-secrets-of-e-commerce-in-china/", "snippet": "There are three major differences between the way e-commerce works in the United States and in China.", "lead_paragraph": "There has been much buzz about the initial public offering of Alibaba, China\u2019s e-commerce giant. The company is the top player in an increasingly crowded and diverse Chinese online sales market that features corporations looking to order large quantities of manufactured goods; small business buying items in lots of, say, 25 pieces; {"abstract": "For less than the price of a plane ticket to China, Export Now promised to ship a small business\u2019s goods to China and put them online in a massive market. Most small businesses were not interested.", "lead_paragraph": "We\u2019ve just published a conversation with Frank Lavin, who introduced an e-commerce platform two years ago, Export Now, that was conceived as an easy, low-cost way for American small businesses to sell their goods in China. {"abstract": "When I bought a company in California last year, I was struck by how similar the bureaucratic hoops were. There actually were more of them in California than I typically face in China.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/09/22/battling-red-tape-in-america-and-china/", "snippet": "When I bought a company in California last year, I was struck by how similar the bureaucratic hoops were. There actually were more of them in California than I typically face in China.", "lead_paragraph": "We all carry stereotypes, especially of people we have yet to meet and places we have yet to visit. Sometimes these stereotypes are reinforced by movies and literature, which makes me cringe: I hate to think that foreigners might conclude that Mrs. Cleaver of \u201cLeave it to Beaver\u201d is representative of American women or that John Wayne\u2019s callused tough guys who grit their way through anything are typical of American men.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Battling Red Tape, in America and China", "kicker": "You're the Boss", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Bribery and Kickbacks", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Small Business", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "United States Economy", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Weidenhamer, Deb", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Auction Systems Auctioneers and Appraisers Inc", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "California", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 7, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2014-09-22T19:39:25+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Entrepreneurship", "byline": {"original": "By Deb Weidenhamer", "person": [{"firstname": "Deb", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Weidenhamer", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/59bb8b3f-e3f4-59be-80e3-35e3c41a79e1", "word_count": 690, "uri": "nyt://article/59bb8b3f-e3f4-59be-80e3-35e3c41a79e1"}

{"abstract": "A slowdown in the pace of growth of China\u2019s economy is leading foreign investors to reassess the country as a destination for their money.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/21/business/international/to-invest-or-not-as-china-shifts.html", "snippet": "A slowdown in the pace of growth of China\u2019s economy is leading foreign investors to reassess the country as a destination for their money.", "lead_paragraph": "HONG KONG \u2014 On a tour of central Henan Province in May of last year, China\u2019s president, Xi Jinping, first raised the notion of the economy adjusting to a \u201cnew normal.\u201d Eight months later, with the economy growing at its slowest pace in more than two decades, it is increasingly clear what this adjustment will mean for China.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "To Invest, or Not, as China Shifts", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Economic Conditions and Trends", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "International Trade and World Market", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Foreign Investments", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-01-20T17:57:32+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "International Business", "byline": {"original": "By Neil Gough", "person": [{"firstname": "Neil", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Gough", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/5ff8d262-245b-5c64-b996-0bd25722269e", "word_count": 906, "uri": "nyt://article/5ff8d262-245b-5c64-b996-0bd25722269e"}

{"abstract": "Following the deal, BBVA will continue to hold a 4.7 percent stake in the Chinese bank.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2015/01/23/bbva-agrees-to-sell-stake-in-china-citic-bank-for-1-7-billion/", "snippet": "Following the deal, BBVA will continue to hold a 4.7 percent stake in the Chinese bank.", "lead_paragraph": "LONDON \u2013 The Spanish lender BBVA said on Friday that it had agreed to sell a 4.9 percent stake in China Citic Bank to the Chinese real estate developer Xinhu Zhongbao for 13.1 billion Hong Kong dollars, or about $1.7 billion.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "BBVA Agrees to Sell Stake in China Citic Bank for $1.7 Billion", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria SA", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "China International Trust & Investment Corp", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Citic Group", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-01-23T14:40:49+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Chad Bray", "person": [{"firstname": "Chad", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Bray", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/755e2d15-dc58-5135-943a-1b91fb69c609", "word_count": 138, "uri": "nyt://article/755e2d15-dc58-5135-943a-1b91fb69c609"}

{"abstract": "Alibaba\u2019s run-in with a Chinese regulator serves as a reminder that there is no such thing as a good relationship with China\u2019s government, John Foley of Reuters Breakingviews writes.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2015/01/29/alibabaa-lesson-in-government-relations/", "snippet": "Alibaba\u2019s run-in with a Chinese regulator serves as a reminder that there is no such thing as a good relationship with China\u2019s government, John Foley of Reuters Breakingviews writes.", "lead_paragraph": "Alibaba is teaching its shareholders a useful lesson about Chinese business: There is no such thing as having a good relationship with the government. The company\u2019s shares fell 4.4 percent on Wednesday after a regulator lambasted its sales habits. Alibaba says the State Administration for Industry and Commerce is being irrational. {"abstract": "By cutting its growth target to approximately 7 percent, China is emphasizing more sustainable growth.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/05/business/china-lowers-official-economic-growth-target.html", "snippet": "By cutting its growth target to approximately 7 percent, China is emphasizing more sustainable growth.", "lead_paragraph": "HONG KONG \u2014 China on Thursday lowered its economic growth target for this year to \u201capproxmately 7 percent,\u201d a significant if widely anticipated development that signals the Communist Party\u2019s determination to shift to more sustainable development.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "China Lowers Official Economic Growth Target", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Economic Conditions and Trends", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Gross Domestic Product", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Communist Party of China", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Li Keqiang", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-03-05T01:46:06+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Neil Gough", "person": [{"firstname": "Neil", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Gough", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/4ce0995d-9425-5118-95bf-7784721b3fa3", "word_count": 519, "uri": "nyt://article/4ce0995d-9425-5118-95bf-7784721b3fa3"}

{"abstract": "Sales in the United States and Canada fell about 5 percent in 2014, but in China they rose 34 percent.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/12/business/media/global-movie-ticket-sales-rise-1-as-china-surges.html", "snippet": "Sales in the United States and Canada fell about 5 percent in 2014, but in China they rose 34 percent.", "lead_paragraph": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 The world movie box office was up 1 percent last year from 2013, but ticket sales in the United States and Canada fell about 5 percent as growth became concentrated in China, the Motion Picture Association of America said on Wednesday.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Global Movie Ticket Sales Rise 1% as China Surges", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Business Briefing; Movie Ticket Sales Rise, Fueled by Growth in China", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Motion Picture Assn of America", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Movies", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-03-11T20:25:34+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Michael Cieply", "person": [{"firstname": "Michael", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Cieply", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/f7bae454-7294-5b02-b3f8-72d24217b444", "word_count": 342, "uri": "nyt://article/f7bae454-7294-5b02-b3f8-72d24217b444"}

{"abstract": "Earnings have disappointed as copper and coal have tumbled. And looking forward, both rivals\u2019 behavior and Chinese demand remain unpredictable.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/20/business/dealbook/glencore-tripped-up-by-faith-in-rational-markets.html", "snippet": "Earnings have disappointed as copper and coal have tumbled. And looking forward, both rivals\u2019 behavior and Chinese demand remain unpredictable.", "lead_paragraph": "Glencore\u2019s shtick has long been that it is the master of the commodity markets. It knows when to take risks, it can shift supply to where it\u2019s most wanted and it tweaks its own mines to maximise profit. Or at least it can do all that when everyone else behaves rationally. That thinking has come unstuck, and the British-Swiss commodities trader\u2019s earnings have gone with it. They halved in the first six months of 2015.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Glencore Tripped Up by Faith in Rational Markets", "kicker": "Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Metals and Minerals", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Mines and Mining", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Commodities", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Coal", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Glencore International AG", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Xstrata", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "China", "rank": 7, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-08-19T19:47:51+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "DealBook", "byline": {"original": "By John Foley", "person": [{"firstname": "John", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Foley", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/024b1163-2bd2-5c58-bbef-7f9fb50cf659", "word_count": 347, "uri": "nyt://article/024b1163-2bd2-5c58-bbef-7f9fb50cf659"}

{"abstract": "The investment bank joins a long list of counterfeits that includes Apple stores and British villages. They\u2019re easy to mock, but they show an ingenuity and pluck that could be powerful.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/28/business/dealbook/a-fake-goldman-sachs-underlines-a-real-chinese-strength.html", "snippet": "The investment bank joins a long list of counterfeits that includes Apple stores and British villages. {"abstract": "Although overall bad debt levels remain relatively low, continued deterioration threatens to reverse years of profit growth.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/01/business/dealbook/slowing-growth-exposes-chinese-banks-debt-debris.html", "snippet": "Although overall bad debt levels remain relatively low, continued deterioration threatens to reverse years of profit growth.", "lead_paragraph": "China\u2019s economic slowdown is exposing the debt debris in its banking sector. {"abstract": "The falling renminbi may be a sign that China sees currency devaluation as a solution to its economic woes. {"abstract": "Traders and portfolio managers worry that sophisticated institutional investors, who generally tend to take a longer-term view, have been the ones driving the selling over the last six
